questions.text: A 45-year-old vegetarian patient recovering from COVID-19 at home developed progressive weakness, fatigue, and tingling sensations in hands and feet. He mentions avoiding all supplements during recovery due to fear of overdose. His diet mainly consisted of plain rice and boiled vegetables for the past 3 months. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for his symptoms? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12 deficiency

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Vitamin B12 deficiency is the correct answer. In this case, the patient's strict vegetarian diet without supplementation, combined with possible COVID-related reduced absorption, puts them at high risk for B12 deficiency. B12 deficiency commonly presents with:
  • • Peripheral neuropathy (tingling sensations) Progressive weakness and fatigue Megaloblastic anemia Cognitive symptoms
  • • Peripheral neuropathy (tingling sensations)
  • • Progressive weakness and fatigue
  • • Megaloblastic anemia
  • • Cognitive symptoms
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Vitamin D deficiency: While common in COVID patients, Vitamin D deficiency primarily presents with bone pain, muscle weakness, and increased risk of fractures. It doesn't typically cause peripheral neuropathy as the primary symptom.
  • • Option A. Vitamin D deficiency:
  • • Option C. Vitamin B6 deficiency: While B6 deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy, it's relatively rare in developed countries and usually requires severe malnutrition. The symptoms are usually less prominent than B12 deficiency.
  • • Option C. Vitamin B6 deficiency:
  • • Option D. Vitamin B3 deficiency: Niacin deficiency (pellagra) presents with dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. While neurological symptoms can occur, peripheral neuropathy is not a prominent feature.
  • • Option D. Vitamin B3 deficiency:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ B12 deficiency is common in:
  • ➤ Strict vegetarians/vegans Malabsorption conditions Post-viral states affecting absorption Elderly patients Those with pernicious anemia
  • ➤ Strict vegetarians/vegans
  • ➤ Malabsorption conditions
  • ➤ Post-viral states affecting absorption
  • ➤ Elderly patients
  • ➤ Those with pernicious anemia
  • ➤ Early recognition is crucial as prolonged deficiency can cause irreversible neurological damage. Treatment requires supplementation, with initial parenteral therapy often needed in severe cases.
  • ➤ Normal serum B12 levels are 200-900 pg/mL, with deficiency typically diagnosed at levels below 200 pg/mL. The recommended daily allowance is 2.4 mcg/day for adults.

questions.text: The active site of enzyme is complimentary to: ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Substrate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective here is to understand the concept of the active site of an enzyme and its relationship to substrates. The active site of an enzyme is complimentary to the substrate, allowing specific interactions that enable the enzyme to catalyze a particular chemical reaction. It stabilizes the transition state of the reaction, facilitating the conversion of substrates into products.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme activity decreases in fasting? ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Phosphofructokinase 1

questions.text: The graph shown below is the titration curve of a biochemical compound. Which of the following statement is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B

options.label: B
options.text: ﻿﻿﻿The points A and B represent the range of maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl group

options.label: C
options.text: ﻿﻿﻿The compound has three ionisable side chains

questions.correct_answer: A. The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The points A and B on the titration curve represent the maximum buffering capacity of the compound, corresponding to the pKa values of the ionizable groups. The graph shown likely represents an amino acid like glycine, which has two ionizable groups.

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is not a feature of refeeding syndrome? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Refeeding syndrome is characterized by hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia, not hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented to the casualty with confusion, ataxia, and painful eye movements. What could be the vitamin deficiency seen in this patient?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin B deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wernicke encephalopathy – An acute, reversible but life-threatening condition. Clinical Vignette include Confusion, Ophthalmoplegia, Nystagmus, Ataxia.

questions.text: Which of the following can be mediated by CRISPR CAS 9 technology? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) DNA editing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common end-product of fatty acid synthesis pathway? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Palmitic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fatty acids are synthesized from acetyl CoA mainly by a de novo synthetic pathway operating in the cytoplasm referred to as extramitochondrial or cytoplasmic fatty acid synthase system.
  • ➤ The major fatty acid synthesized de novo is palmitic acid, the 16C saturated fatty acid . The process occurs in liver, adipose tissue, kidney, brain, and mammary glands.
  • ➤ The major fatty acid synthesized de novo is palmitic acid, the 16C saturated fatty acid
  • ➤ Beta oxidation of fatty acids breaks it down into Acetyl CoA.
  • ➤ Defect in pathway - Inhibition of lipogenesis occurs in type 1 (insulin-dependent) diabetes mellitus, and variations in its activity affect the nature and extent of obesity.
  • ➤ Defect in pathway

questions.text: What components constitute the backbone of a DNA molecule?(NEET PG 2015)
questions.correct_answer: D. Alternating phosphate and sugar groups
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Alternating phosphate and sugar groups

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The DNA molecule has a backbone made up of alternating deoxyribose sugar and phosphate groups connected by 3',5'-phosphodiester bonds. This structure creates the "backbone" of DNA, while the nitrogenous bases (A, T, G, C) project inward from this backbone and form the base pairs that constitute the genetic information. The phosphodiester bonds connecting the sugar-phosphate backbone give DNA its directional nature, with one end having a 5' phosphate and the other having a 3' hydroxyl group.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Alternating sugars and nitrogenous bases: Incorrect because nitrogenous bases are not part of the backbone but rather project inward to form base pairs between the two strands of DNA.
  • • Option A. Alternating sugars and nitrogenous bases:
  • • Option B. Nitrogenous bases alone: Incorrect because bases are attached to the sugar components of the backbone via N-glycosidic bonds but do not themselves form the backbone structure.
  • • Option B. Nitrogenous bases alone:
  • • Option C. Phosphate groups alone: Incorrect because phosphate groups alternate with deoxyribose sugar molecules to form the backbone; phosphates alone would not create the required structure.
  • • Option C. Phosphate groups alone:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The DNA backbone consists of alternating deoxyribose sugar and phosphate groups connected by 3',5'-phosphodiester bonds, which forms the structural framework of the double helix while the nitrogenous bases attached to the sugars encode the genetic information.

questions.text: In Menke's disease, which of the following enzymes would be affected?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lysyl oxidase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Menke’s kinky hair syndrome is an x-linked defect (affects only male child). It is a condition in which dietary copper is absorbed from GI tract; but cannot be transported to blood due to absence of an intracellular copper binding ATPase ( mutation in ATP7A gene).
  • ➤ Menke’s kinky hair syndrome is an x-linked defect (affects only male child).
  • ➤ mutation in ATP7A gene).
  • ➤ Copper is not mobilized from intestinal cells as well as in other tissue cells . The copper that has entered into the cell is not able to get out of the cells, and so it is accumulated. Hence, copper is not available for metabolism, resulting in defective cross-linking of connective tissue. Vascular and connective tissues are affected, and child dies usually in infancy . Deficiency of copper results in defective function of lysyl oxidase .
  • ➤ Copper is not mobilized from intestinal cells as well as in other tissue cells
  • ➤ child dies usually in infancy
  • ➤ defective function of lysyl oxidase

questions.text: Which of the following does not favor euchromatin formation due to changes occurring at Cytosine residues at Cp islands in DNA?(AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Methylation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methylation of cytosine residues at CpG islands is associated with gene silencing and the formation of transcriptionally inactive heterochromatin, thus not favoring euchromatin formation.

questions.text: Which of the following are vitamin-B12 dependent enzymes? ( INICET Nov 2020) Methylmalonyl Co isomerase Homocysteine synthase Folate reductase Methionine synthase
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1 and 4 only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The enzymes methylmalonyl CoA isomerase and methionine synthase are dependent on vitamin B12. These enzymes play critical roles in metabolic pathways, including amino acid catabolism and methylation reactions.

questions.text: Xanthurenic Acid in urine indicates: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6 deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In individuals with a deficiency of vitamin B6 (pyridoxine), the conversion of tryptophan to niacin (vitamin B3) is impaired. As a result, tryptophan is metabolized through an alternative pathway, leading to the accumulation of xanthurenic acid. Therefore, the presence of xanthurenic acid in urine is indicative of a vitamin B6 deficiency.

questions.text: Enzyme activated by a decrease in insulin: glucagon ratio is? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glucose 6-phosphatase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Low insulin glucagon ratio means it is fasting state, as in fed state insulin is more. So in fasting state glucose-6-phosphatase will be active as this enzyme is involved in gluconeogenesis , which occurs during fasting. Phosphofructokinase is involved in glycolysis. PFK-1 is active in any situation and PFK-2 is active only in fed state. Glucokinase phosphorylates glucose in liver and pancreas, active in fed state and is induced by insulin. Hexokinase also phosphorylates glucose and is present in all cells of the body. It is active in any situation in body as it is a general enzyme to phosphorylate glucose.
  • ➤ Low insulin glucagon ratio means it is fasting state, as in fed state insulin is more. So in fasting state glucose-6-phosphatase will be active as this enzyme is involved in gluconeogenesis , which occurs during fasting.
  • ➤ So in fasting state glucose-6-phosphatase will be active as this enzyme is involved in gluconeogenesis
  • ➤ Phosphofructokinase is involved in glycolysis. PFK-1 is active in any situation and PFK-2 is active only in fed state.
  • ➤ Glucokinase phosphorylates glucose in liver and pancreas, active in fed state and is induced by insulin.
  • ➤ Hexokinase also phosphorylates glucose and is present in all cells of the body. It is active in any situation in body as it is a general enzyme to phosphorylate glucose.
  • ➤ Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 137-138
  • ➤ Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 137-138

questions.text: Which of the following is the best screening investigation for metabolic disorders?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tandem mass spectrometry

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) is the preferred method for screening metabolic disorders due to its ability to simultaneously analyze multiple metabolites with high sensitivity and specificity.

questions.text: Vitamin C cannot be produced in humans due to lack of? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) L-gulonolactone oxidase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Humans cannot synthesize vitamin C due to the lack of the enzyme L-gulonolactone oxidase, which is necessary for the final step in the biosynthetic pathway of ascorbic acid from glucose.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding an allosteric modifier? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: B
options.text: Causes the enzyme to work faster only

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Participates in feedback regulation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Allosteric Regulation
  • ➤ Allosteric Regulation
  • ➤ Allosteric enzyme has one catalytic site where the substrate binds and another separate allosteric site where the modifier binds (allo = other). Allosteric and substrate binding sites may or may not be physically adjacent. The binding of the regulatory molecule can either enhance the activity of the enzyme ( allosteric activation ), or inhibit the activity of the enzyme ( allosteric inhibition ). In the former case, the regulatory molecule is known as the positive modifier and in the latter case as the negative modifier . The binding of substrate to one of the subunits of the enzyme may enhance substrate binding by other subunits. This effect is said to be positive cooperativity . If the binding of substrate to one of the subunits decreases the avidity of substrate binding by other sites, the effect is called negative cooperativity. In feedback mechanism, one of the intermediates or products will go back and bind to the allosteric site of one of the enzymes involved in the series of reactions, thereby either inhibiting or activating the enzyme.
  • ➤ Allosteric enzyme has one catalytic site where the substrate binds and another separate allosteric site where the modifier binds (allo = other).
  • ➤ one catalytic site
  • ➤ separate allosteric site
  • ➤ Allosteric and substrate binding sites may or may not be physically adjacent.
  • ➤ The binding of the regulatory molecule can either enhance the activity of the enzyme ( allosteric activation ), or inhibit the activity of the enzyme ( allosteric inhibition ).
  • ➤ allosteric activation
  • ➤ allosteric inhibition
  • ➤ In the former case, the regulatory molecule is known as the positive modifier and in the latter case as the negative modifier .
  • ➤ positive modifier
  • ➤ negative modifier
  • ➤ The binding of substrate to one of the subunits of the enzyme may enhance substrate binding by other subunits. This effect is said to be positive cooperativity . If the binding of substrate to one of the subunits decreases the avidity of substrate binding by other sites, the effect is called negative cooperativity.
  • ➤ positive cooperativity
  • ➤ negative cooperativity.
  • ➤ In feedback mechanism, one of the intermediates or products will go back and bind to the allosteric site of one of the enzymes involved in the series of reactions, thereby either inhibiting or activating the enzyme.

questions.text: During prolonged fasting, a patient's muscles break down proteins for gluconeogenesis, producing significant amounts of ammonia. Which amino acid primarily transports this ammonia from muscle to liver? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alanine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Alanine is the correct answer. During fasting or exercise, muscle protein breakdown produces significant ammonia. The glucose-alanine cycle is the primary pathway for transporting this ammonia from muscle to liver because:
  • • Pyruvate accepts amino groups to form alanine in muscle Alanine safely carries nitrogen to liver In liver, alanine is deaminated to produce pyruvate for gluconeogenesis The released ammonia enters the urea cycle
  • • Pyruvate accepts amino groups to form alanine in muscle
  • • Alanine safely carries nitrogen to liver
  • • In liver, alanine is deaminated to produce pyruvate for gluconeogenesis
  • • The released ammonia enters the urea cycle
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Glutamate: While glutamate participates in transamination reactions, it's not the primary carrier of ammonia from muscle to liver. It typically donates its amino group to form alanine in muscle.
  • • Option A. Glutamate:
  • • Option D. Glutamine: Although glutamine is the primary carrier of ammonia from brain to liver, it's not the main transporter from muscle to liver. This role belongs to alanine through the glucose-alanine cycle.
  • • Option D. Glutamine:
  • • Option C. Glycine: Glycine, while involved in one-carbon metabolism, does not play a significant role in ammonia transport from muscle to liver.
  • • Option C. Glycine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand:
  • ➤ The glucose-alanine cycle's role in: Ammonia transport from muscle Gluconeogenic substrate provision Muscle protein catabolism during fasting Tissue-specific differences in ammonia transport: Brain → Liver: Glutamine pathway Muscle → Liver: Alanine cycle Integration of amino acid metabolism with: Glucose metabolism Nitrogen disposal Energy homeostasis during fasting
  • ➤ The glucose-alanine cycle's role in: Ammonia transport from muscle Gluconeogenic substrate provision Muscle protein catabolism during fasting
  • ➤ Ammonia transport from muscle Gluconeogenic substrate provision Muscle protein catabolism during fasting
  • ➤ Ammonia transport from muscle
  • ➤ Gluconeogenic substrate provision
  • ➤ Muscle protein catabolism during fasting
  • ➤ Tissue-specific differences in ammonia transport: Brain → Liver: Glutamine pathway Muscle → Liver: Alanine cycle
  • ➤ Brain → Liver: Glutamine pathway Muscle → Liver: Alanine cycle
  • ➤ Brain → Liver: Glutamine pathway
  • ➤ Muscle → Liver: Alanine cycle
  • ➤ Integration of amino acid metabolism with: Glucose metabolism Nitrogen disposal Energy homeostasis during fasting
  • ➤ Glucose metabolism Nitrogen disposal Energy homeostasis during fasting
  • ➤ Glucose metabolism
  • ➤ Nitrogen disposal
  • ➤ Energy homeostasis during fasting

questions.text: Best method for detection of chromosomal translocations in leukemia is? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) FISH

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization (FISH) is the gold standard for detecting chromosomal translocations in leukemia. FISH provides direct visualization of specific chromosomal rearrangements using fluorescent-labeled probes that bind to specific DNA sequences, allowing detection of both numerical and structural chromosomal abnormalities.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Next-generation sequencing: While NGS can detect translocations, it requires complex bioinformatics analysis and may miss some structural variants. It's more suitable for comprehensive genomic profiling rather than rapid translocation detection.
  • • Option A. Next-generation sequencing:
  • • Option C. Digital droplet PCR: Although highly sensitive for detecting point mutations and copy number variations, ddPCR requires prior knowledge of breakpoints and is not ideal for initial detection of chromosomal translocations.
  • • Option C. Digital droplet PCR:
  • • Option D. Real-time PCR: While useful for quantifying specific known translocations, real-time PCR cannot detect novel or unexpected chromosomal rearrangements and requires prior knowledge of breakpoint sequences.
  • • Option D. Real-time PCR:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ FISH advantages for translocation detection:
  • ➤ Direct visualization of chromosomal abnormalities Can be performed on non-dividing cells Rapid turnaround time High sensitivity and specificity Ability to detect cryptic translocations Useful for monitoring disease progression Can detect multiple abnormalities simultaneously
  • ➤ Direct visualization of chromosomal abnormalities
  • ➤ Can be performed on non-dividing cells
  • ➤ Rapid turnaround time
  • ➤ High sensitivity and specificity
  • ➤ Ability to detect cryptic translocations
  • ➤ Useful for monitoring disease progression
  • ➤ Can detect multiple abnormalities simultaneously

questions.text: A patient present with an X-ray showing cardiomegaly, along with symptoms of hypotonia, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, and "floppy baby" syndrome. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pompe's disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pompe's disease is characterized by the combination of cardiomegaly, muscle hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and macroglossia, often presenting as "floppy baby" syndrome due to lysosomal storage of glycogen.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with post-transcriptional modification? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glycosylation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glycosylation is not a post-transcriptional modification. Post-transcriptional modifications include processes like capping, methylation, and splicing, which are critical for the maturation of mRNA before it is translated into protein.

questions.text: Common precursor amino acid for urea, creatine and nitric oxide is? ( NEET PG 2019)

Ans. B) Arginine

  • ➤ Creatine is synthesized from 3 amino acids : glycine, arginine and methionine (GAME)
  • ➤ : glycine, arginine and methionine
  • ➤ (GAME)

questions.text: This child is suffering from: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Kwashiorkor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kwashiorkor is a Protein energy malnutrition caused by inadequate intake of protein with good calorie intake. C/F: abdominal and peripheral edema (swollen belly and legs) due to decreased serum albumin levels. Body fat stores are depleted, but weight for height is normal.
  • ➤ Kwashiorkor is a Protein energy malnutrition caused by inadequate intake of protein with good calorie intake.
  • ➤ C/F: abdominal and peripheral edema (swollen belly and legs) due to decreased serum albumin levels.
  • ➤ Body fat stores are depleted, but weight for height is normal.
  • ➤ Treatment – diet adequate in calories and protein.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 532-533
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 532-533

questions.text: Under anaerobic metabolism which of the following substrates yields 3 molecules of ATP? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glycogen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Under anaerobic conditions, glycogen yields 3 molecules of ATP per glucose unit because it enters glycolysis as glucose-6-phosphate, bypassing the initial ATP-consuming step of glycolysis.

questions.text: FAD status in body is determined by?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glutathione reductase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ FAD is the active form of Vitamin B 2 and marker for the B 2 deficiency is RBC glutathione reductase activity as this enzyme require B 2 as coenzyme. So, in case of FAD deficiency, glutathione reductase activity will be lowered without affecting the quantity of enzyme.

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 534

questions.text: The enzyme that is not used in cholesterol synthesis? ( INICET May 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) HMG CoA lyase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ HMG CoA lyase is not used in the cholesterol synthesis pathway; it is involved in ketogenesis.

questions.text: Which of the following deficiencies is associated with sexual maturation defect and hypogonadism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Zn (Zinc)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zinc deficiency is directly linked to hypogonadism and delayed sexual maturation, along with other symptoms such as impaired wound healing, decreased immunity, and chronic diarrhea. Recognizing and correcting zinc deficiency is crucial for preventing these clinical outcomes.

questions.text: A family consumes only polished rice. Which of the following combination of vitamin deficiency and enzymatic defect will be present in this family? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thiamine – Transketolase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The consumption of polished rice leads to thiamine deficiency which leads to defective transketolase activity.
  • ➤ Polished rice undergoes milling, which removes the outer bran layer rich in B vitamins and other nutrients

questions.text: Refsum’s disease is caused by the defect of? ( INICET Nov 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Beta oxidation of branched chain fatty acid

options.label: B
options.text: Alpha oxidation of branched chain fatty acid

options.label: C
options.text: Omega oxidation of branched chain fatty acid

questions.correct_answer: B. Alpha oxidation of branched chain fatty acid
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alpha oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Characteristic of Peroxisomal pathways:
  • ➤ Characteristic of Peroxisomal pathways:
  • ➤ No ATP production in any of peroxisomal pathways H 2 O 2 is regularly formed which is neutralized by peroxisomal enzymes catalase & peroxidase. Two pathways which occur in peroxisomes are:
  • ➤ No ATP production in any of peroxisomal pathways
  • ➤ H 2 O 2 is regularly formed which is neutralized by peroxisomal enzymes catalase & peroxidase.
  • ➤ Two pathways which occur in peroxisomes are:
  • ➤ 1. α-Oxidation of branched chain fatty acids (BCFA)
  • ➤ 2. Oxidation of Very Long Chain Fatty Acid (VLCFA)
  • ➤ Refsum's disease: Occur due to defect in α-oxidation of BCFA in peroxisomes due to defect in phytanic acid hydroxylase. So, Phytanic acid not oxidised.
  • ➤ Refsum's disease:
  • ➤ Beta-oxidation occurs for saturated and even chain fatty acids like palmitic and stearic acid In Omega-oxidation dicarboxylic acids are formed. In MCAD deficiency there is dicarboxylic acidosis and non-ketotic hypoglycemia.
  • ➤ Beta-oxidation occurs for saturated and even chain fatty acids like palmitic and stearic acid
  • ➤ In Omega-oxidation dicarboxylic acids are formed. In MCAD deficiency there is dicarboxylic acidosis and non-ketotic hypoglycemia.

questions.text: Lactulose is ? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Galactose and fructose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lactulose is composed of galactose and fructose, differentiating it from lactose, which is made up of galactose and glucose. It is commonly used for its medicinal properties, particularly as a laxative.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibitor in the graph? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Competitive inhibitor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is a Lineweaver-Burk plot of enzyme kinetics, with 1/v (inverse of velocity) on the Y-axis and 1/[S] (inverse of substrate concentration) on the X-axis. The red line represents the inhibitor, and the blue line represents the normal substrate.
  • • In the presence of a competitive inhibitor, the Km (Michaelis constant) increases while the Vmax (maximum velocity) remains unchanged. This is evident in the graph where the slope increases, indicating an increased Km, but the Y-intercept, representing 1/Vmax, stays the same.
  • • For non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases while Km remains unchanged. This would be shown by an increase in the Y-intercept, which is not the case here.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Non-competitive inhibitor: In non-competitive inhibition, the Vmax decreases while the Km remains unchanged. This would be reflected in the graph by an increased Y-intercept (1/Vmax) while the slope remains the same, which is not observed here.
  • • Option B. Non-competitive inhibitor:
  • • Option C. Allosteric inhibitor: Allosteric inhibitors bind to a site other than the active site and can either increase or decrease enzyme activity, affecting both Km and Vmax. The specific effects depend on the nature of the allosteric inhibition, which is not represented by the given Lineweaver-Burk plot.
  • • Option C. Allosteric inhibitor:
  • • Option D. Uncompetitive inhibitor: Uncompetitive inhibitors bind only to the enzyme-substrate complex, decreasing both Km and Vmax. This would be shown by parallel lines in the Lineweaver-Burk plot, which is not seen in the provided graph.
  • • Option D. Uncompetitive inhibitor:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Competitive inhibitors increase the Km without affecting the Vmax, which is shown by an increase in the slope of the Lineweaver-Burk plot without changing the Y-intercept.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 77

questions.text: Cytochrome C oxidase is inhibited by all EXCEPT?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Methane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CN, CO and H2S are inhibitors of Cytochrome c Oxidase (Complex IV of ETC). They inhibit by non-competitive inhibition and this type of inhibition is mostly irreversible. For a complete list of ETC inhibitors refer to table below:
  • ➤ Inhibitor of ETC complexes
  • ➤ Inhibitor of ETC complexes

  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/p 123

questions.text: DNA methylation is not related to?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Capping

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DNA methylation is not related to RNA capping, which is an mRNA modification process. Instead, it is involved in processes such as mismatch repair, chromatin remodeling, and gene silencing.

questions.text: Which of the following methods uses RNA? ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) RT-PCR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RT-PCR is a method for detection of gene expression using reverse transcription of RNA to synthesize cDNA. Western Blot most commonly involve antigen-antibody interactions which is a.protein-protein interaction. Sanger’s method is a DNA sequencing technique by chain termination of DNA polymerization using DNA as template. G-banding is a chromosomal staining technique usually done for karyotyping analysis and involve only DNA.
  • ➤ Ref- Lehninger 6 th e/p 331
  • ➤ Ref-
  • ➤ Lehninger 6 th e/p
  • ➤ 331

questions.text: Most radio-resistant phase of cell cycle? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) S

questions.text: A 55-year-old Mediterranean man has significantly lower rates of cardiovascular disease compared to his Western counterparts despite having similar risk factors. His diet is rich in olives and olive oil. Which fatty acid predominantly present in his diet is most likely responsible for the cardioprotective effect? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Omega 9 FA

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Omega-9 fatty acids (particularly oleic acid) are the correct answer. The Mediterranean diet, rich in olive oil, is associated with reduced cardiovascular risk primarily due to its high omega-9 content. Omega-9 fatty acids provide cardioprotection through:
  • • Reducing LDL cholesterol levels Increasing HDL cholesterol Improving insulin sensitivity Decreasing inflammation Enhancing endothelial function
  • • Reducing LDL cholesterol levels
  • • Increasing HDL cholesterol
  • • Improving insulin sensitivity
  • • Decreasing inflammation
  • • Enhancing endothelial function
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Saturated Fatty Acid: Saturated fatty acids are generally associated with increased cardiovascular risk due to their effects on raising LDL cholesterol and promoting inflammation. They are not cardioprotective.
  • • Option A. Saturated Fatty Acid:
  • • Option B. Omega 3 FA: While omega-3 fatty acids are cardioprotective, they are not the predominant fatty acids in olive oil or the Mediterranean diet. They are more commonly found in fish and certain seeds.
  • • Option B. Omega 3 FA:
  • • Option C. Omega 6 FA: Though essential, excessive omega-6 fatty acids can promote inflammation when consumed in high ratios compared to omega-3. They are not the characteristic fatty acids of the Mediterranean diet.
  • • Option C. Omega 6 FA:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Mediterranean diet's cardioprotective effects are attributed to:
  • ➤ High monounsaturated fat (omega-9) content from olive oil Balanced omega-6:omega-3 ratio Low saturated fat intake Rich in polyphenols and antioxidants
  • ➤ High monounsaturated fat (omega-9) content from olive oil
  • ➤ Balanced omega-6:omega-3 ratio
  • ➤ Low saturated fat intake
  • ➤ Rich in polyphenols and antioxidants
  • ➤ Omega-9 fatty acids (oleic acid) constitute about 55-83% of olive oil composition. The recommended intake of monounsaturated fats should be 15-20% of total daily calories for cardiovascular benefits.

questions.text: Apolipoprotein B 48 is a made of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) RNA editing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In liver cell, Apo B100 gene gives rise to Apo B 100 protein. But Apo B48 protein is made in intestinal cells from the gene encoding Apo B100, by the process of RNA editing, which is also known as Differential RNA processing or chemical modification of RNA. This is a post transcriptional modification.
  • ➤ Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 238
  • ➤ Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 238

questions.text: Which of the following are Methanol poisoning derivatives? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Formic acid + Lactic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methanol poisoning primarily results in the formation of formic acid and lactic acid as toxic metabolites.

questions.text: Which Glycogen Storage Disease listed below does not typically result in Hypoglycemia? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Type II (Pompe's Disease)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Type II glycogen storage disease (Pompe's disease) is characterized by deficiency of lysosomal acid maltase (acid α-glucosidase). Unlike the other listed disorders, Pompe's disease affects glycogen breakdown in lysosomes rather than in the cytosol. The disease primarily manifests with accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes of multiple tissues - especially heart, muscle, and brain - causing cardiomegaly, muscle weakness, and neurological symptoms. Pompe's disease does not typically present with hypoglycemia as the primary metabolic derangement.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Type I (Von Gierke's Disease): This is incorrect because Von Gierke's disease, caused by glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency, is characterized by severe hypoglycemia. The enzyme defect prevents the liver from releasing glucose into the bloodstream.
  • • Option A. Type I (Von Gierke's Disease):
  • • Option B. Type III (Cori's Disease): This is incorrect because Cori's disease (debranching enzyme deficiency) does present with hypoglycemia, although it's typically less severe than in Type I. Mild hypoglycemia or early morning hypoglycemia is a characteristic.
  • • Option B. Type III (Cori's Disease):
  • • Option D. Type VI (Hers' Disease): This is incorrect because Hers' disease (liver phosphorylase deficiency) does present with hypoglycemia, although it's generally mild. Mild hypoglycemia is a feature of this disorder.
  • • Option D. Type VI (Hers' Disease):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pompe's disease (Type II GSD) affects lysosomal glycogen breakdown and primarily presents with cardiac, muscular, and neurological symptoms rather than hypoglycemia, which is a prominent feature of GSDs affecting hepatic glucose release (Types I, III, and VI).

questions.text: Reason of Hepatomegaly in Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Accumulation of glycogen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is known as Von Gierke’s disease or Type I GSD.
  • ➤ Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is known as Von Gierke’s disease or Type I GSD.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes are involved in gluconeogenesis? ( INICET Nov 2020) A. Pyruvate carboxylase B. Phosphoenol pyruvate kinase C. Hexokinase D. Pyruvate kinase E. Glucose 6 phosphatase
questions.correct_answer: A. A, B and E only
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A, B and E only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The enzymes pyruvate carboxylase, phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase, and glucose-6-phosphatase are essential for gluconeogenesis, a metabolic pathway that synthesizes glucose from non-carbohydrate substrates.

questions.text: Which of the following is the reason for using phenylbutyrate in urea cycle disorders? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It scavenges nitrogen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phenylbutyrate is used in urea cycle disorders to scavenge nitrogen by reacting with glutamine, converting excess ammonia into phenylacetylglutamine, which is then excreted in the urine.

questions.text: You are expected to produce a protein of interest. Arrange the following steps in a sequence. Lysis of bacterial cell Incorporating gene of interest into bacteria SDS-PAGE Hybridization Protein elution/extraction Expression of protein (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) b-f-a-c-d-e

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The steps of Recombinant DNA technology for expressing a gene of interest for production of a desired protein in E. coli cell.
  • • The steps of Recombinant DNA technology are:
  • • The steps of Recombinant DNA technology are:
  • • b) Incorporating gene of interest into bacteria: The gene of interest is inserted into a vector such as a plasmid, which is then introduced into the host E. coli cell to produce recombinant E. coli. f) Expression of protein: The recombinant E. coli is grown in a suitable medium to express the protein inside the cells. a) Lysis of bacterial cell: The bacterial cells are lysed to extract the expressed protein. c) SDS-PAGE: The extracted protein is purified using SDS-PAGE electrophoresis. d) Hybridization: The protein is identified and confirmed by western blotting or hybridization. e) Protein elution/extraction: Finally, the protein is eluted or extracted for subsequent use.
  • • b) Incorporating gene of interest into bacteria: The gene of interest is inserted into a vector such as a plasmid, which is then introduced into the host E. coli cell to produce recombinant E. coli.
  • • b) Incorporating gene of interest into bacteria:
  • • f) Expression of protein: The recombinant E. coli is grown in a suitable medium to express the protein inside the cells.
  • • f) Expression of protein:
  • • a) Lysis of bacterial cell: The bacterial cells are lysed to extract the expressed protein.
  • • a) Lysis of bacterial cell:
  • • c) SDS-PAGE: The extracted protein is purified using SDS-PAGE electrophoresis.
  • • c) SDS-PAGE:
  • • d) Hybridization: The protein is identified and confirmed by western blotting or hybridization.
  • • d) Hybridization:
  • • e) Protein elution/extraction: Finally, the protein is eluted or extracted for subsequent use.
  • • e) Protein elution/extraction:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

References:

  • ↳ References: Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 432-438

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness, anemia, bony pain & hepatosplenomegaly. A histological picture is shown with cells in bone marrow. Which of the following enzyme is deficient?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gluco-Cerebrosidase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gluco-Cerebrosidase, is associated with Gaucher's disease, a rare inherited metabolic disorder characterized by the accumulation of harmful quantities of glucosylceramide due to the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. Gaucher's disease can lead to the symptoms described, including hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, and bony pain.
  • ➤ Ref -Harper 31 st e/pg. 235
  • ➤ Ref -Harper 31 st e/pg. 235

questions.text: A neonate on breast feeding develops jaundice. Urine Benedict’s test is positive. The enzyme deficiency is_________: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Galactose-1-P Uridyl Transferase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The neonate's symptoms, including jaundice and a positive Benedict's test for reducing sugars in the urine, are indicative of galactosemia. In galactosemia, there is a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase, which is involved in the conversion of galactose-1-phosphate to glucose-1-phosphate. Gal-1-P accumulates causes product inhibition of galactokinase resulting in galactose accumulation which comes out in urine giving positive Benedict’s test.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 198
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 198

questions.text: Methotrexate reduces the synthesis of: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) TMP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, leading to reduced synthesis of TMP by limiting tetrahydrofolate availability.

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is caused by the defect of which of the following organelles?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Peroxisomes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In Zellweger syndrome, there are empty peroxisomes in all body cells causing defect in alpha-oxidation and oxidation of VLCFA. So, both phytanic acid and VLCFA accumulate. It is the most severe Peroxisomal Biogenesis Disorder (PBD).

questions.text: Which of the following TCA cycle intermediate is a part of heme metabolism? ( AIIMS May 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Succinyl CoA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Important anabolic reactions related with citric acid cycle are:
  • ➤ Important anabolic reactions
  • ➤ Oxaloacetate is the precursor of aspartate Alpha ketoglutarate can be made into glutamate Succinyl CoA is used for synthesis of heme Mitochondrial citrate is transported to cytoplasm, where it is cleaved into acetyl CoA, which then is the starting point of fatty acid synthesis.
  • ➤ Oxaloacetate is the precursor of aspartate
  • ➤ Oxaloacetate
  • ➤ Alpha ketoglutarate can be made into glutamate
  • ➤ Alpha ketoglutarate
  • ➤ Succinyl CoA is used for synthesis of heme
  • ➤ Succinyl CoA
  • ➤ Mitochondrial citrate is transported to cytoplasm, where it is cleaved into acetyl CoA, which then is the starting point of fatty acid synthesis.
  • ➤ Mitochondrial citrate
  • ➤ starting point of fatty acid synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids are conjugated to the steroid nucleus of bile acids?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glycine and taurine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Bile acids, derived from cholesterol, are essential for the digestion and absorption of fats. The liver synthesizes two primary bile acids: cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid. These bile acids are then conjugated with the amino acids glycine or taurine to form bile salts, which are more effective in emulsifying fats. The conjugation process enhances the solubility and functionality of bile acids in the aqueous environment of the digestive tract.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Glycine and alanine: Alanine is not involved in the conjugation of bile acids.
  • • Option B. Glycine and alanine:
  • • Option C. Histidine and glycine: Histidine is not used for conjugation with bile acids.
  • • Option C. Histidine and glycine:
  • • Option D. Glutamic acid and valine: Neither glutamic acid nor valine are involved in bile acid conjugation.
  • • Option D. Glutamic acid and valine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glycine and taurine are the amino acids conjugated to the steroid nucleus of bile acids, forming bile salts.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not involved in iron metabolism? ( AIIMS May 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Transthyretin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Cherry red spots on retina and mental retardation is seen in: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tay Sach’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hallmark feature of Tay-Sachs disease is the presence of "cherry red spots" on the retina of the eye. These spots are a distinctive sign observed during eye examinations. Additionally, individuals with Tay-Sachs disease often experience progressive neurological deterioration, including muscle weakness, loss of motor skills, and seizures. There is also a characteristic decline in cognitive function, leading to intellectual and developmental disability.

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 235

questions.text: A patient presents with severe muscle cramps, constipation, and ECG changes showing prolonged QT interval. Daily dietary analysis reveals adequate calcium intake but deficiency of another element essential for neuromuscular function. Which of the following mineral deficiency is most likely responsible for these symptoms? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Magnesium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Magnesium is the correct answer. Although like calcium it's a macromineral (>100 mg/day requirement), magnesium deficiency presents with:
  • • Neuromuscular manifestations (cramps, tetany) Cardiac conduction abnormalities (prolonged QT) Gastrointestinal symptoms (constipation) Muscle weakness Irritability and confusion in severe cases
  • • Neuromuscular manifestations (cramps, tetany)
  • • Cardiac conduction abnormalities (prolonged QT)
  • • Gastrointestinal symptoms (constipation)
  • • Muscle weakness
  • • Irritability and confusion in severe cases
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Copper: Copper is a micronutrient (<100 mg/day). Its deficiency primarily affects hematopoiesis and can cause anemia. It doesn't typically cause the presenting symptoms.
  • • Option A. Copper:
  • • Option C. Chromium: Chromium is a trace element. Its deficiency mainly affects glucose metabolism and insulin function, not neuromuscular or cardiac function.
  • • Option C. Chromium:
  • • Option D. Iodine: Iodine is a micronutrient essential for thyroid hormone synthesis. Deficiency causes goiter and hypothyroidism but doesn't directly cause acute neuromuscular symptoms.
  • • Option D. Iodine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand:
  • ➤ Classification of minerals based on daily requirements: Macrominerals (>100 mg/day): Ca, P, Na, K, Cl, Mg, S Microminerals (<100 mg/day): Fe, Fl, Cu, Co, Cr, Mn, Mo, Zn, I, Se Clinical manifestations of magnesium deficiency Role of magnesium in: Neuromuscular function Cardiac conduction Enzyme cofactor ATP metabolism Importance of distinguishing between macro and micromineral deficiencies in clinical presentations
  • ➤ Classification of minerals based on daily requirements: Macrominerals (>100 mg/day): Ca, P, Na, K, Cl, Mg, S Microminerals (<100 mg/day): Fe, Fl, Cu, Co, Cr, Mn, Mo, Zn, I, Se
  • ➤ Macrominerals (>100 mg/day): Ca, P, Na, K, Cl, Mg, S Microminerals (<100 mg/day): Fe, Fl, Cu, Co, Cr, Mn, Mo, Zn, I, Se
  • ➤ Macrominerals (>100 mg/day): Ca, P, Na, K, Cl, Mg, S
  • ➤ Microminerals (<100 mg/day): Fe, Fl, Cu, Co, Cr, Mn, Mo, Zn, I, Se
  • ➤ Clinical manifestations of magnesium deficiency
  • ➤ Role of magnesium in: Neuromuscular function Cardiac conduction Enzyme cofactor ATP metabolism
  • ➤ Neuromuscular function Cardiac conduction Enzyme cofactor ATP metabolism
  • ➤ Neuromuscular function
  • ➤ Cardiac conduction
  • ➤ Enzyme cofactor
  • ➤ ATP metabolism
  • ➤ Importance of distinguishing between macro and micromineral deficiencies in clinical presentations

questions.text: The following graph is most likely to be seen in: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Non-competitive inhibition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Features of Non-competitive Inhibition
  • ➤ Features of Non-competitive Inhibition
  • ➤ The inhibitor binds to a different site on the enzyme, other than the substrate binding site and the inhibitor has no structural resemblance to substrate and hence, excess substrate does not abolish the inhibition. The inhibitor combines with the enzymes by a covalent bond, which makes the reaction irreversible. The velocity (Vmax) is reduced and the Km value is not changed , because the remaining enzyme molecules have the same affinity for the substrate.
  • ➤ The inhibitor binds to a different site on the enzyme, other than the substrate binding site and the inhibitor has no structural resemblance to substrate and hence, excess substrate does not abolish the inhibition.
  • ➤ The inhibitor combines with the enzymes by a covalent bond, which makes the reaction irreversible.
  • ➤ The velocity (Vmax) is reduced and the Km value is not changed , because the remaining enzyme molecules have the same affinity for the substrate.
  • ➤ velocity (Vmax) is reduced
  • ➤ Km value is not changed
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 80-81
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 80-81

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient who is used to taking alcohol for the last 25 years suddenly presented with agitation and confusion. There were gait abnormalities. On enquiry, the person gave a history of alcohol withdrawal for 3 days. Identify the condition: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Delirium tremens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Delirium tremens is a life-threatening condition that occurs during alcohol withdrawal, characterized by confusion, agitation, tremors, and often hallucinations

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy, a known case of type I DM, undergoes the following test for the detection of KB. Which is this test: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rothera's Test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rothera's Test is a commonly used laboratory test to detect the presence of ketone bodies, specifically acetoacetate, in urine or blood samples. It is particularly relevant in the context of diabetes mellitus, as individuals with uncontrolled diabetes, especially type I diabetes, may experience an increase in ketone production.
  • ➤ In type I diabetes, the body is unable to produce sufficient insulin, resulting in a lack of glucose utilization by cells for energy. As a result, the body begins to break down fats as an alternative energy source, leading to the production of ketone bodies, including acetoacetate.

questions.text: A patient presented with symptoms of peripheral neuropathy and macrocytic anemia. She was given folate 5mg and the blood picture improved. However, the neurologic manifestations were aggravated. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: B
options.text: Treatment with folate unmasking pyridoxine deficiency

options.label: C
options.text: Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS

options.label: D
options.text: Folate therapy using the B12 stores

questions.correct_answer: D. Folate therapy using the B12 stores
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Folate therapy using the B12 stores

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Folic acid doses over 1 mg may cause aggravation of vitamin B12 deficiency and may precipitate nerve damage .
  • ➤ Folic acid doses over 1 mg may cause aggravation of vitamin B12 deficiency and may precipitate nerve damage
  • ➤ The most likely cause is folate therapy which used up the B12 stores, aggravating the symptoms.
  • ➤ Administration of folic acid for patients with macrocytic anemia can partially reverse the hematologic abnormalities associated with vitamin B12 deficiency. However, the neurologic manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency are not treated by folic acid.
  • ➤ However, the neurologic manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency are not treated by folic acid.
